\chapter{Introduction}
\label{\detokenize{reference/introduction:introduction}}\label{\detokenize{reference/introduction:id1}}\label{\detokenize{reference/introduction::doc}}
Welcome to SpyDrNet, a tool that will help you analyze and transform
\sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netlist}{netlists}. SpyDrNet is developed and maintained by the
\sphinxhref{https://ccl.ee.byu.edu/}{Configurable Computing Lab} of \sphinxhref{https://www.byu.edu/}{Brigham Young University}. This tool is related to the \sphinxhref{http://reliability.ee.byu.edu/edif/}{BYU EDIF Tools} and is
considered to be the next generation tool for FPGA netlist analysis and transformation.


\section{SpyDrNet Getting Started}
\label{\detokenize{reference/introduction:spydrnet-getting-started}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Installation}

This package will be available on Python Package Index shortly. Once it is, the stable release of SpyDrNet can be installed using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pip}}:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{pip} \PYG{n}{install} \PYG{n}{spydrnet}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

To install from PyPI with all optional dependicies use:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{pip} \PYG{n}{install} \PYG{n}{spydrnet}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n+nb}{all}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

SpyDrNet can also be installed from a source archive:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{pip} \PYG{n}{install} \PYG{n}{spydrnet}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.}\PYG{n}{tar}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{gz}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Or a built distribution:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{pip} \PYG{n}{install} \PYG{n}{spydrnet}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{py3}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{none}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{any}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{whl}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If a development environment is desired, the project can be installed in editable mode from the project directory:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{pip} \PYG{n}{install} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{e} \PYG{o}{.}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstylestrong{Tool Flow}

Netlists flow through SpyDrNet in a three step process (see \hyperref[\detokenize{reference/introduction:fig-flow}]{Fig.\@ \ref{\detokenize{reference/introduction:fig-flow}}}). First, they are parsed by a \sphinxstyleemphasis{parser} into an intermediate representation (IR). Second, their IR is analyzed and transformed. Finally, their IR is composed by a \sphinxstyleemphasis{composer} back into a netlist format that a 3rd\sphinxhyphen{}party tool can use. This flow is inspired by \sphinxhref{http://www.aosabook.org/en/llvm.html}{LLVM} and \sphinxhref{https://pandoc.org/}{Pandoc}. LLVM has a similar flow for compiling computer programs and Pandoc has a similar flow for converting document formats. Using this flow, SpyDrNet is designed to be able to work on any netlist.

\begin{figure}[H]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{flow}.pdf}
\caption{Flow}\label{\detokenize{reference/introduction:id3}}\label{\detokenize{reference/introduction:fig-flow}}\end{figure}

SpyDrNet can be used to create a netlist from scratch. Thus, the API can be used to implement a parser and composer for arbitrary formats.

\sphinxstyleemphasis{Parsing a netlist}

SpyDrNet currently includes a parser for EDIF:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}netlist\PYGZus{}filename\PYGZgt{}.edf}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstyleemphasis{Composing a netlist}

SpyDrNet currently includes a composer for EDIF:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{compose}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}filename\PYGZgt{}.edf}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{netlist}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstylestrong{Loading SpyDrNet}

To load \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet}}, import it into a Python interactive interpreter or code:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{spydrnet} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n+nn}{sdn}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

At this point, SpyDrNet features and functionality are accessible via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sdn.\textless{}function/feature\textgreater{}}}. The abbreviation of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sdn}} is used throughout code examples to reference the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet}} package.

\sphinxstylestrong{Intermediate Representation Basics}

Digital designs for FPGAs are represented as netlists, a list of components and connections. Netlists come from various vendors in many different formats. SpyDrNet allows you to look at and alter a netlist in a language inspecific way. SpyDrNet parses a netlist into an intermediate represention (IR) that is designed to be easily traversed and effortlessly manipulated. SpyDrNet aims to provide the tools you need to accomplish the netlist analysis and transformation tasks you have in mind without having to reinvent the wheel. \hyperref[\detokenize{reference/introduction:fig-ir}]{Fig.\@ \ref{\detokenize{reference/introduction:fig-ir}}} shows a summary of the SpyDrNet intermediate representation (IR).

\begin{figure}[H]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{IR}.pdf}
\caption{Intermediate Representaion}\label{\detokenize{reference/introduction:id4}}\label{\detokenize{reference/introduction:fig-ir}}\end{figure}

SpyDrNet’s intermediate representation of netlists (IR) is what sets it apart for other EDA tools. The IR is structured to house netlists in a generic way while allowing for format specific constructs to be preserved.
\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Element}}}] \leavevmode
Most IR classes inherit from this Python class. Objects of this class are referred to as a netlist elements. A netlist
element contains a dictionary for storing data specific to itself. This is accomplished using Python get/set item
functions, (see {\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/element_data:sec-element-data}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Element Data}}}}).

\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/netlist:spydrnet.Netlist}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Netlist}}}}}}] \leavevmode
This class of Python objects is the netlist element with the highest level of organization (a whole netlist). It
contains an ordered collection of libraries and any data associated with the netlist as a whole.

\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/library:spydrnet.Library}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Library}}}}}}] \leavevmode
This netlist element contains an ordered collection of cell or module definitions associated with a library.

\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/definition:spydrnet.Definition}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Definition}}}}}}] \leavevmode
A definition outlines the contents of each component that can be instantiated elsewhere in the design. It holds information that is pertinant to all instances of itself including subcomponents ports and connections

\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/instance:spydrnet.Instance}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Instance}}}}}}] \leavevmode
This element holds pointers to the definition which it instances, and contains its own set of pins to be connected to within its parent definition.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Bundle}}}] \leavevmode
The Bundle class is a parent class of Ports and Cables because each can be thought of as an array. This class defines the structure that helps us properly represent array objects in netlists including the width, direction (to or downto) and starting index. As a parent class this class is not directly instantiated in netlist.

\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/port:spydrnet.Port}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Port}}}}}}] \leavevmode
The Port element inherits from Bundles and can be thought of as containing the information on how a Definition connects the outside world to the elements it contains.

\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/cable:spydrnet.Cable}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Cable}}}}}}] \leavevmode
Cables are bundles of connectors between components within a definition. They connect ports to their destination pins

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Pin}}}] \leavevmode
The pin class is also a parent class, inherited from by the inner pin and outer pin objects. Unlike the Element and Bundle objects, Pins are useful because they can hide some of the implementation details of the underlying inner pins and outer pins.

\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/innerpin:spydrnet.InnerPin}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{InnerPin}}}}}}] \leavevmode
These pins are collected in Ports and are contained on the inside of the definitions. There is one set of inner pins per definition but they could refer to several sets of OuterPins

\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/outerpin:spydrnet.OuterPin}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{OuterPin}}}}}}] \leavevmode
These pins are collected on instances. They let us distinguish between connections to multiple instances of a single definition. These objects remove the need to carefuly track hierarcy while navegating a netlist.

\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/wire:spydrnet.Wire}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Wire}}}}}}] \leavevmode
Wires are grouped inside cables and are elements that help hold connection information between single pins on instances within a definition and within it’s ports.

\end{description}

More detail on the IR is provided in {\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/index:api-summary}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{API Summary}}}}.


\section{Aracnid Etymology}
\label{\detokenize{reference/introduction:aracnid-etymology}}
Spiders are masters at spinning webs. These webs often created like nets are stronger than steel when stretched and much more elastic. SpyDrNet aims to give end users the ability to pass these traits on to their netlists by enabling reliability and other applications through generic analysis and transformations on netlist. Of course this is just scratching the surface of the ways in which this name is applicable to the tool. Finding these fun meanings is (as it is said in academia) left as an exercise to the curious reader. For now we would rather discuss what this tool can be used to do.


\section{Other Information}
\label{\detokenize{reference/introduction:other-information}}
SpyDrNet is part of a rising ecosystem of free and open source software (FOSS) for FPGA development. Consider \sphinxhref{http://www.myhdl.org/}{MyHDL}, \sphinxhref{https://pyeda.readthedocs.io/en/latest/}{PyEDA}, \sphinxhref{http://www.clifford.at/yosys/}{Yosys}, \sphinxhref{https://github.com/masc-ucsc/livehd}{LiveHD}, \sphinxhref{https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~alanmi/abc/}{ABC}, \sphinxhref{http://www.cs.columbia.edu/~cs6861/sis/blif/index.html}{BLIF}, \sphinxhref{https://www.rapidwright.io/}{RapidWright}, \sphinxhref{http://rapidsmith.sourceforge.net/}{RapidSmith}, \sphinxhref{https://github.com/byuccl/RapidSmith2}{RapidSmith2}, \sphinxhref{http://www.jhdl.org/}{JHDL}, \sphinxhref{http://reliability.ee.byu.edu/edif/}{BYU EDIF Tools}, VQM, and \sphinxhref{https://github.com/SymbiFlow/prjxray}{Project X\sphinxhyphen{}ray}.


\chapter{Element Data}
\label{\detokenize{reference/element_data:element-data}}\label{\detokenize{reference/element_data:sec-element-data}}\label{\detokenize{reference/element_data::doc}}
Each netlist element allows for arbitrary data to be associated with it. This is accomplished using a Python \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dict}}.


\section{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{reference/element_data:keys}}
Keys are ought to be strings with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.}} seperated namespaces. Element properties from the originating netlist format
belong in the root namespace (without any \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.}}). The NULL namespace (keys with a leading \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.}}) is reserved for use by
SpyDrNet. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{element}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{.NAME}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{name\PYGZus{}of\PYGZus{}element}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textquotesingle{}.NAME\textquotesingle{}}} key in this example is the key \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NAME}} in the NULL namespace. The key is reserved for the reference
name of elements.

Language specific constructs can be sored under key entries within the namespace of the specific language. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{EDIF}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{edifVersion}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

The key value par stores the EDIF version used by an EDIF netlist.


\section{Setting Data}
\label{\detokenize{reference/element_data:setting-data}}
Data is set using the Python \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\_\_setitem\_\_}} magic function meaning that data can be set using this syntax:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{element}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}key\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{value}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Getting Data}
\label{\detokenize{reference/element_data:getting-data}}
Data can be read through itteration:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{key} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{element}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{key}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{element}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{key}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Or by using the using the Python \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\_\_getitem\_\_}} magic function by itself:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{element}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}key\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{value}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

A read only view of the data dictionary can be obtained from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{element.data}}. The returned object acts and feels like
a Python dictionary, but mutator functions are disabled. This allows for the automated managment of the dictionary.


\section{Deleting Data}
\label{\detokenize{reference/element_data:deleting-data}}
Entries in the dictionary can be deleted using the \sphinxtitleref{\_\_delitem\_\_} magic function as follows:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k}{del} \PYG{n}{element}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}key\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\chapter{API Summary}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/index:api-summary}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/index::doc}}
The SpyDrNet API can be used to create, analyze, and transform a netlist. Netlist are represented in memory in an Intermediate Representation. \hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/index:fig-exampleir}]{Fig.\@ \ref{\detokenize{reference/classes/index:fig-exampleir}}} show the representation of a simple circuit in the SpyDrNet Intermediate Representation.
If you would like an example of using the SpyDrNet tool to create a netlist like this, click \DUrole{xref,std,std-ref}{here}

\begin{figure}[H]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{ExampleCircuit}.png}
\caption{Example Netlist in the Intermediate Representaion}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/index:id2}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/index:fig-exampleir}}\end{figure}

The API calls documented here can be used in Python as follows:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} create an empty netlist and add an empty library to it}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{spydrnet} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n+nn}{sdn}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ir}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Netlist}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{library} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{netlist}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{create\PYGZus{}library}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Similarly if the parser is used the calls can be made in the same way:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} parse an edif file in and add an empty library to the netlist.}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{spydrnet} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n+nn}{sdn}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{four\PYGZus{}bit\PYGZus{}counter.edf}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{library} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{netlist}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{create\PYGZus{}library}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Basic object types}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/index:basic-object-types}}

\subsection{Netlist}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/netlist:netlist}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/netlist:id1}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/netlist::doc}}

\subsubsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/netlist:overview}}\index{Netlist (class in spydrnet)@\spxentry{Netlist}\spxextra{class in spydrnet}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/netlist:spydrnet.Netlist}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{Netlist}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{name}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{properties}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
Represents a netlist object.

Contains a top level instance and libraries
\subsubsection*{Examples}

After importing the spydrnet package, we can initialize the netlist from scratch

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{spydrnet} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n+nn}{sdn}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Netlist}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

We can also initalize an top instance for the netlist. For more info: {\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/instance:instance}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Instance}}}}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{top\PYGZus{}instance} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Instance}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{top\PYGZus{}instance} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{top\PYGZus{}instance}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

This is the way to set up a top level definition for the netlist

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{top\PYGZus{}definition} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Definition}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{top\PYGZus{}instance} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{top\PYGZus{}definition}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

We can initialize a “primatives” and a “work” library this way:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{primitives\PYGZus{}library} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{netlist}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{create\PYGZus{}library}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{primitives\PYGZus{}library}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{EDIF.identifier}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{hdi\PYGZus{}primitives}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{work\PYGZus{}library} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{netlist}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{create\PYGZus{}library}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{work\PYGZus{}library}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{EDIF.identifier}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{work}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\item {}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\paragraph{spydrnet.Library.remove\_definitions\_from}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Library.remove_definitions_from:spydrnet.Library.remove_definitions_from}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Library.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{remove\_definitions\_from}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{definitions}}}{}
Remove a set of definitions from the library.

All definitions provided must be in the library.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstylestrong{Definitions \sphinxhyphen{} Set of Definition type objects} \textendash{} The definitions to be removed

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}



\paragraph{spydrnet.Library.clone}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Library.clone:spydrnet-library-clone}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Library.clone::doc}}\index{clone() (spydrnet.Library method)@\spxentry{clone()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Library method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Library.clone:spydrnet.Library.clone}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Library.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{clone}}}{}{}
Clone the library in an API safe manner.

The following describes the structure of the returned object:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
the instances that pointed to reference definitions within the library will have updated references

\item {} 
the instances that pointed to reference definitions outside the library will maintain their definitions

\item {} 
the references lists (of definitions) both inside and outsde the library will be updated to reflect the change

\item {} 
all definitions are cloned within the library.

\end{itemize}

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsection{Definition}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/definition:definition}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/definition:id1}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/definition::doc}}

\subsubsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/definition:overview}}\index{Definition (class in spydrnet)@\spxentry{Definition}\spxextra{class in spydrnet}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/definition:spydrnet.Definition}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{Definition}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{name}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{properties}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
Represents a definition of a cell, module, entity/architecture, or paralleled structure object.

Contains a pointer to parent library, ports, cables, and instances.

\end{fulllineitems}

\paragraph{spydrnet.Definition.is\_leaf}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Definition.is_leaf:spydrnet-definition-is-leaf}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Definition.is_leaf::doc}}\index{is\_leaf() (spydrnet.Definition method)@\spxentry{is\_leaf()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Definition method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Definition.is_leaf:spydrnet.Definition.is_leaf}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Definition.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{is\_leaf}}}{}{}
Check to see if this definition represents a leaf cell.

Leaf cells are cells with no children instances or no
children cables. Blackbox cells are considered leaf cells as well as direct pass through cells with cables only

\end{fulllineitems}

\subparagraph{spydrnet.Definition.create\_child}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Definition.create_child:spydrnet-definition-create-child}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Definition.create_child::doc}}\index{create\_child() (spydrnet.Definition method)@\spxentry{create\_child()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Definition method}}

Create an instance to add to the definition, add it, and return the instance.

This functions calls the add\_child funciton.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{name \sphinxhyphen{} (str) the name of this instance}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{properties \sphinxhyphen{} (dict) the dictionary which holds the properties}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}
\subsubsection*{Example}

To create a child:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{definition} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Definition}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{child\PYGZus{}instance} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{definition}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{create\PYGZus{}child}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{child\PYGZus{}instance}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{child\PYGZus{}instance}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{child\PYGZus{}instance}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{reference} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{reference\PYGZus{}definition}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

To create a child with optional parameters

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{child\PYGZus{}instance} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{definition}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{create\PYGZus{}child}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{child\PYGZus{}instance}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{reference}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{reference\PYGZus{}definition}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

The reference of the instance is the definition that initialized this instance.

\end{fulllineitems}

Add an existing instance to the definition.

This instance must not already be included in a definition.
It add the instance as a child into the given position.
Append to the end of the list if no position is given.
It will set the parent of the instance to this definition.

\subparagraph{spydrnet.Definition.clone}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Definition.clone:spydrnet-definition-clone}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Definition.clone::doc}}\index{clone() (spydrnet.Definition method)@\spxentry{clone()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Definition method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Definition.clone:spydrnet.Definition.clone}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Definition.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{clone}}}{}{}
Clone the definition in an api safe way.

The cloned object will have the following properties
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
the definition will be orphaned and will not belong to any library

\item {} 
each of the sub elements of the definition will also be cloned and the connection structure between them will be updated.

\item {} 
the cloned instances will still point to the reference to which the pointed before. They will also be members of the references list of those definitions.

\end{itemize}

\end{fulllineitems}



\subparagraph{spydrnet.Definition.get\_libraries}

\subsection{Instance}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/instance:instance}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/instance:id1}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/instance::doc}}

\subsubsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/instance:overview}}\index{Instance (class in spydrnet)@\spxentry{Instance}\spxextra{class in spydrnet}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/instance:spydrnet.Instance}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{Instance}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{name}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{properties}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
Netlist instance of a netlist definition.

Instances are literally instances of definitions and they reside inside definitions.
Function names have been set to adjust for the potential confusion that could arise because instances both have a parent definition and have definitions which they reference.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Variables}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Instance.parent:spydrnet.Instance.parent}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{parent}}}}} \textendash{} the parent of the object. Parent is the definition of the instance that contains the current instance.

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Instance.reference:spydrnet.Instance.reference}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{reference}}}}} \textendash{} the item of the object. Reference is the definition of the instance that instantiated or defined the current instance.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\paragraph{spydrnet.Instance.clone}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Instance.clone:spydrnet-instance-clone}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Instance.clone::doc}}\index{clone() (spydrnet.Instance method)@\spxentry{clone()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Instance method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Instance.clone:spydrnet.Instance.clone}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Instance.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{clone}}}{}{}
Clone the instance in an api safe way.
This call will return a cloned instance that has the following properties:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
the pins in the instance will all be disconnected from wires but they will maintain their references to inner pins

\item {} 
the instance references is the same as the cloned object

\item {} 
the reference’s references list contains this instance

\item {} 
the instance is orphaned (no longer a child of the definition to which the cloned definition belonged

\end{itemize}

\end{fulllineitems}



\paragraph{spydrnet.Instance.get\_netlists}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Instance.get_netlists:spydrnet-instance-get-netlists}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Instance.get_netlists::doc}}\index{get\_netlists() (spydrnet.Instance method)@\spxentry{get\_netlists()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Instance method}}

\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/port:overview}}\index{Port (class in spydrnet)@\spxentry{Port}\spxextra{class in spydrnet}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/port:spydrnet.Port}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{Port}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{name}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{properties}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{is\_downto}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{is\_scalar}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{lower\_index}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{direction}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
Located on the inside of a definition.

Ports contain information about the quantity and directon of pins that go into and out of the defined struture when instanced.

\end{fulllineitems}

\paragraph{spydrnet.Port.remove\_pin}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Port.remove_pin:spydrnet-port-remove-pin}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Port.remove_pin::doc}}\index{remove\_pin() (spydrnet.Port method)@\spxentry{remove\_pin()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Port method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Port.remove_pin:spydrnet.Port.remove_pin}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Port.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{remove\_pin}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{pin}}}{}
Remove the given pin from the port.

The pin must belong to the port in order to be removed. Wires are disconnected from the pin that is removed.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstylestrong{pin \sphinxhyphen{} (Pin) a pin to be removed from the port.}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}



\paragraph{spydrnet.Port.remove\_pins\_from}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Port.remove_pins_from:spydrnet-port-remove-pins-from}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Port.remove_pins_from::doc}}\index{remove\_pins\_from() (spydrnet.Port method)@\spxentry{remove\_pins\_from()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Port method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Port.remove_pins_from:spydrnet.Port.remove_pins_from}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Port.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{remove\_pins\_from}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{pins}}}{}
Remove several pins from the port at once.

The wires are disconnected from the pins that are removed.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstylestrong{pins \sphinxhyphen{} (List of Pin objects) a list of all pins to be removed from the port.}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}



\paragraph{spydrnet.Port.clone}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Port.clone:spydrnet-port-clone}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Port.clone::doc}}\index{clone() (spydrnet.Port method)@\spxentry{clone()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Port method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Port.clone:spydrnet.Port.clone}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Port.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{clone}}}{}{}
Clone the port in an api safe way.

The following rules will be observed:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
all the pins will be disconnected from wires

\item {} 
the port will be orphaned

\item {} 
all pins will belong to the returned port

\item {} 
direction, downto, is\_scalar, lower\_index will all be maintained

\end{itemize}

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsection{InnerPin}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/innerpin:innerpin}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/innerpin:id1}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/innerpin::doc}}

\subsubsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/innerpin:overview}}\index{InnerPin (class in spydrnet)@\spxentry{InnerPin}\spxextra{class in spydrnet}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/innerpin:spydrnet.InnerPin}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{InnerPin}}}
Pins that correspond to definitions.

These pins can be thought of as on the inside of a definition. There can be
many outer pins for each inner pin

\end{fulllineitems}

\paragraph{spydrnet.InnerPin.clone}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.InnerPin.clone:spydrnet-innerpin-clone}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.InnerPin.clone::doc}}\index{clone() (spydrnet.InnerPin method)@\spxentry{clone()}\spxextra{spydrnet.InnerPin method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.InnerPin.clone:spydrnet.InnerPin.clone}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{InnerPin.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{clone}}}{}{}
Clone the inner pin in an api safe way.

The following conditions will be met:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
The inner pin will be orphaned from any ports

\item {} 
The pin will not be connected to any wires

\item {} 
The pin will not be referenced to by any wires or outer pins

\end{itemize}

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsection{OuterPin}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/outerpin:outerpin}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/outerpin:id1}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/outerpin::doc}}

\subsubsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/outerpin:overview}}\index{OuterPin (class in spydrnet)@\spxentry{OuterPin}\spxextra{class in spydrnet}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/outerpin:spydrnet.OuterPin}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{OuterPin}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{instance}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{inner\_pin}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
Pins that correspond to instances. These pins can be thought of as on the outside of an instance. There can be many
outer pins for each inner pin

\end{fulllineitems}

\paragraph{spydrnet.OuterPin.clone}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.OuterPin.clone:spydrnet-outerpin-clone}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.OuterPin.clone::doc}}\index{clone() (spydrnet.OuterPin method)@\spxentry{clone()}\spxextra{spydrnet.OuterPin method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.OuterPin.clone:spydrnet.OuterPin.clone}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{OuterPin.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{clone}}}{}{}
Clone the pin in an api safe way.

The following conditions will be met with the returned outer pin:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
the pin will not be connected to any wires

\item {} 
the pin will be orphaned from any instance

\item {} 
the pin will not be connected to any inner pins

\end{itemize}

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsection{Cable}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/cable:cable}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/cable:id1}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/cable::doc}}

\subsubsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/cable:overview}}\index{Cable (class in spydrnet)@\spxentry{Cable}\spxextra{class in spydrnet}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/cable:spydrnet.Cable}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{Cable}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{name}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{properties}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{is\_downto}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{is\_scalar}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{lower\_index}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
Representino of several wires in a collection.

Much like Ports cable extend the bundle class, giving them indexing ability they represent several wires in a collection or bus that are generally related.
This could be thought of much like vector types in VHDL ie std\_logic\_vector (7 downto 0)

\end{fulllineitems}

\paragraph{spydrnet.Cable.create\_wire}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.create_wire:spydrnet-cable-create-wire}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.create_wire::doc}}\index{create\_wire() (spydrnet.Cable method)@\spxentry{create\_wire()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Cable method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.create_wire:spydrnet.Cable.create_wire}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Cable.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{create\_wire}}}{}{}
Creates a wire and adds it to the cable. Returns the wire that was created

\end{fulllineitems}



\paragraph{spydrnet.Cable.add\_wire}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.add_wire:spydrnet-cable-add-wire}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.add_wire::doc}}\index{add\_wire() (spydrnet.Cable method)@\spxentry{add\_wire()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Cable method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.add_wire:spydrnet.Cable.add_wire}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Cable.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{add\_wire}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{wire}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{position}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
Adds a wire to the cable at the given position. This wire must not belong to a cable already
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{wire \sphinxhyphen{} (Wire) the wire to be added to the cable. This wire must not belong to any other cable.}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{position \sphinxhyphen{} (int, default None) the index in the wires list at which to add the wire.}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}



\paragraph{spydrnet.Cable.create\_wires}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.create_wires:spydrnet-cable-create-wires}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.create_wires::doc}}\index{create\_wires() (spydrnet.Cable method)@\spxentry{create\_wires()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Cable method}}

\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstylestrong{wire\_count \sphinxhyphen{} (int) the number of wires to be added to the cable.}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}



\paragraph{spydrnet.Cable.remove\_wire}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.remove_wire:spydrnet-cable-remove-wire}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.remove_wire::doc}}\index{remove\_wire() (spydrnet.Cable method)@\spxentry{remove\_wire()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Cable method}}

\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstylestrong{wire \sphinxhyphen{} (Wire) the wire to be removed from the cable.}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}



\paragraph{spydrnet.Cable.remove\_wires\_from}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.remove_wires_from:spydrnet-cable-remove-wires-from}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.remove_wires_from::doc}}\index{remove\_wires\_from() (spydrnet.Cable method)@\spxentry{remove\_wires\_from()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Cable method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.remove_wires_from:spydrnet.Cable.remove_wires_from}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Cable.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{remove\_wires\_from}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{wires}}}{}
Remove all wires given from the cable. Each must be a member of this cable.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstylestrong{wires \sphinxhyphen{} (List of Wire objects) wires to be removed from the cable.}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}



\paragraph{spydrnet.Cable.clone}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.clone:spydrnet-cable-clone}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.clone::doc}}\index{clone() (spydrnet.Cable method)@\spxentry{clone()}\spxextra{spydrnet.Cable method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.Cable.clone:spydrnet.Cable.clone}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Cable.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{clone}}}{}{}
Clone the Cable and all of its wires in an api safe way
the following will be true of the returned cable
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
The cable will be orphaned from any definitions

\item {} 
the wires in the cable will not be connected to any pins

\item {} 
is\_downto, is\_scalar, lower\_index will be maintained

\item {} 
the wires in the cable will all have the cable set as the parent

\end{itemize}

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsection{HRef}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/href:href}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/href:id1}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/href::doc}}

\subsubsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/href:overview}}\index{HRef (class in spydrnet.util)@\spxentry{HRef}\spxextra{class in spydrnet.util}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/href:spydrnet.util.HRef}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet.util.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{HRef}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{item}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{parent}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
A hierarchical reference to a specific element in a netlist.

Definitions can be instanced more than once (i.e., multiple instances can reference the same definition).
When a definition is instanced more than once, it causes the contents of the definition to be shared. Therefore, any
changes to a multi\sphinxhyphen{}instanced definition will be reflected in all instances of that definition. Similarly, any
references to the contents of a multi\sphinxhyphen{}instanced definition refer to the contents of all of the instances and not to
the contents of a specific instance. This sharing creates challenges for analyzing and transforming the netlist.

Hierarchical references refer to a netlist element by hierarchical sequence. A hierarchical sequence begins with the
the top\sphinxhyphen{}instance of netlist (see Netlist.top\_instance). The sequence continues with children instances (parent to
child) until the instance of interest is reached. The instance of interest is the final instance in the sequence.
When the referenced element is an instance, the sequence terminates. When the referenced element is a port, pin,
cable, or wire, the sequence continues with those elements until the desired element is specified (e.g., port;
port, pin; cable; or cable, wire. In this way, hierarhical elements are uniquely referenced even though the contents
of a definition may be shared.

\sphinxstylestrong{Hierarchical Sequence Examples:}

Here are some examples of hierarchical sequences:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{Top Instance:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{{[}top\_instance{]}}}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{Top Instance Port}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{{[}top\_instance, port{]}}}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{Top Instance Pin}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{{[}top\_instance, port, pin{]}}}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{Shared Sub\sphinxhyphen{}Instance Cable)}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{{[}top\_instance, sub\_instance\_A, sub\_instance\_C, cable{]}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{{[}top\_instance, sub\_instance\_B, sub\_instance\_C, cable{]}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sub\_instance\_A}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sub\_instance\_B}} are instances (or children) with the definition referenced by
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{top\_instance}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sub\_instance\_A}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sub\_instance\_B}} reference the same definition, which contains \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sub\_instance\_C}}.

\item {} 
Even though \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cable}} is the same element in both sequences, each sequence uniquely references the cable
inside \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sub\_instance\_A}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sub\_instance\_B}} respectively.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxstylestrong{Netlist Analysis and Transformation:}

Hierarchical references provide unique handles on hierarchical elements. A unique handle allows for such elements to
be considered individually even though two hierarchical may point to some of the same elements. This makes it
possible, for example, to consider pin connectivity across hierarchy even though the actual pins may be the same.

In some netlist tranformations, it may be desirable to modify the contents of a specific instance without modifying
the contents of another instance that refers to the same definition. Hierarchical references make it possible to
refer to an instance that should be changed. Once the definition is made unique (see spydrnet.uniquify), then any
alterations will only affect the originally specified instance. Hierarchical instances also allow for uniqueness
checking (see HRef.is\_unique).

\sphinxstylestrong{Hierarchical Reference Representation:}

HRefs represent hierarchy as nodes in a hierarchical tree. The root node is an HRef to the top\_instance of a netlist
with no parent node. Each HRef contains a pointer to its parent HRef (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}} in the case of the root HRef), a
pointer to the element in the netlist that it references, and a hashcode generated from each referenced object.

Storing the hashcode with the object saves on re\sphinxhyphen{}computation and allows for quick operations in containers that
require Hashable objects. If the hashcode were not stored with the object, it would have to be recalculated for
each hash\sphinxhyphen{}dependent operation, which could consume a large amount of computational resources depending on the
hierarchical depth of the node. Parent and item pointers are immutable. The hashcode of a referenced item is also
immutable. Therefore, the hashcode of a HRef should not change during its existence (even if a netlist
transformation renders it invalid).

\sphinxstylestrong{Use of a Flyweight Pattern:}

Due the the nature of hierarchical references, parent nodes can be referenced more than once. Rather than having
multiple hierarchical nodes in memory that point to the same hierarchical parent, a flyweight can be used to save
on memory. A flyweight pattern is used here to share hierarchical parent nodes. See \sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flyweight\_pattern}{Flyweight pattern}.

\sphinxstylestrong{Lack of Parent to Child Pointers:}

A parent to child pointer requires a lookup diction from each child item to each child hierarchical node. This
approach could be taken, but it recreates much of the same information that is available in the original netlist. It
was therefore decided to leverage the flyweight pattern rather than explicitly manage all of the necessary
child\sphinxhyphen{}item to child\sphinxhyphen{}node relationships.


\begin{fulllineitems}
\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{item:~the~item~of~the~object}}}
\end{fulllineitems}



\begin{fulllineitems}
\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{parent:~the~parent~of~the~object}}}
\end{fulllineitems}


\end{fulllineitems}



\subsubsection{Methods}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/href:methods}}

\begin{savenotes}\sphinxatlongtablestart\begin{longtable}[c]{\X{1}{2}\X{1}{2}}
\hline

\subsection{spydrnet.parse}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.parse:spydrnet-parse}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.parse::doc}}\index{parse() (in module spydrnet)@\spxentry{parse()}\spxextra{in module spydrnet}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.parse:spydrnet.parse}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{parse}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{filename}}}{}
The parse function is able to parse either a EDIF (.edf) file or a Verilog file (.v)

This functions also supports the parsing of .zip files. Such as the ones in support\_files folder
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
The netlist that comes as the result of the parsing of the file if the file was parsed successfully

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
{\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/netlist:spydrnet.Netlist}]{\sphinxcrossref{Netlist}}}

\end{description}\end{quote}
\subsubsection*{Examples}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{spydrnet} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n+nn}{sdn}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}netlist\PYGZus{}filename\PYGZgt{}.edf}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Or we can parse a verilog file

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}netlist\PYGZus{}filename\PYGZgt{}.v}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Or a zip file that contains the edif or verilog file

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{4bitadder.edf.zip}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}


The following three classes are the classes from which the above elements inherit. They are included here for completeness of
documentation and can be used if needed. if the above types will suffice it may be simpler to use them.


\begin{savenotes}\sphinxatlongtablestart\begin{longtable}[c]{\X{1}{2}\X{1}{2}}

\endfirsthead

\subsection{spydrnet.ir.FirstClassElement}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.ir.FirstClassElement:spydrnet-ir-firstclasselement}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.ir.FirstClassElement::doc}}\index{FirstClassElement (class in spydrnet.ir)@\spxentry{FirstClassElement}\spxextra{class in spydrnet.ir}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.ir.FirstClassElement:spydrnet.ir.FirstClassElement}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet.ir.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{FirstClassElement}}}
Base class of all intermediate representation objects.

An intermediate representation object represents an item in a netlist. Items range in specificity from pins on a
port or wires in a cable up to an item that represents the netlist as a whole.

Each element implements a dictionary for storing key\sphinxhyphen{}value pairs. The key should be a case sensitive string and the
value should be a primitive type (string, integer, float, boolean) or potentially nested collections of primitive
types. The purpose of this dictionary is to provide a space for properties and metadata associated with the element.

Key namespaces are separated with a \sphinxstyleemphasis{period} character. If the key is void of a \sphinxstyleemphasis{period} than the key resides in the
root namespace. Keys in the root namespace are considered properties. Other keys are considered metadata. For
example ‘\textless{}LANG\_OF\_ORIGIN\textgreater{}.\textless{}METADATA\_TAG\textgreater{}’:\textless{}metadata\_value\textgreater{} is considered metadata associated with the netlist’s
language of origin.

Only data pertinent to the netlist should be stored in this dictionary. Cached data (namespace management, anything
that can be recreated from the netlist) should be excluded from this dictionary. The intent of the IR is to house
the basis of data for the netlist.

The only key that is reserved is ‘NAME’. It is the primary name of the element. NAME may be undefined or inferred,
for example, a pin on a port may be nameless, but infer its name for its parent port and position.
\index{\_\_init\_\_() (spydrnet.ir.FirstClassElement method)@\spxentry{\_\_init\_\_()}\spxextra{spydrnet.ir.FirstClassElement method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.ir.FirstClassElement:spydrnet.ir.FirstClassElement.__init__}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{\_\_init\_\_}}}{}{}
Initialize an element with an empty data dictionary.

\end{fulllineitems}

behavior (if namespace policy uses case insensitive indexing, this parameter will not prevent a fast lookup
from returning a matching object even if the case is not an exact match).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{is\_re} (\sphinxstyleemphasis{bool \sphinxhyphen{} optional, named, default: False}) \textendash{} Specify if patterns are regular expressions. If \sphinxtitleref{False}, a pattern can still contain \sphinxtitleref{*} and \sphinxtitleref{?} wildcards. A
\sphinxtitleref{*} matches zero or more characters. A \sphinxtitleref{?} matches upto a single character.

\item {}

included or not.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{selection} (\sphinxstyleemphasis{Selection.\{INSIDE, OUTSIDE\}, default: INSIDE}) \textendash{} This parameter determines the instances that are returned based on the definition that is being searched. This
parameter only applies to objects that are definitions. If the selection is “INSIDE” (default), then the
function will return all of the instances that are inside the definition (i.e., the definition’s children) that
match the remainder of the search criteria. If the selection is “OUTSIDE”, then the function will return all of
the instances of the provided definition that match the remainder of the search criteria.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{filter} (\sphinxstyleemphasis{function}) \textendash{} This is a single input function that can be used to filter out unwanted virtual instances. If not specifed, all
matching virtual instances are returned. Otherwise, virtual instances that cause the filter function to evaluate
to true are the only items returned.

\subsection{spydrnet.uniquify.uniquify}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.uniquify.uniquify:spydrnet-uniquify-uniquify}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.uniquify.uniquify::doc}}\index{uniquify() (in module spydrnet.uniquify)@\spxentry{uniquify()}\spxextra{in module spydrnet.uniquify}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.uniquify.uniquify:spydrnet.uniquify.uniquify}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet.uniquify.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{uniquify}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{netlist}}}{}
Make the instances in the netlist unique
uniqification is done in place. Each instance will correspond to exactly one definition and each definition will correspond to exactly one instance with the exception of leaf cells.
Leaf cells are can be instanced unlimited numbers of times. Any netlist elements that are not instantiated by the top instance will not be modified and may retain duplicate instances
Currently there is no guarantee that the original definition names will be maintained, but it is guaranteed that they will be unique within the scope of all hardware that is below the top instance.

Renameing is predictable. the string: \_sdn\_unique\_\# will be added to the end of the definition names.

parameter \sphinxhyphen{} netlist, the netlist that will be uniquified

returns \sphinxhyphen{} no returns

\end{fulllineitems}



\begin{savenotes}\sphinxatlongtablestart\begin{longtable}[c]{\X{1}{2}\X{1}{2}}
\hline

\endfirsthead

\multicolumn{2}{c}%
{\makebox[0pt]{\sphinxtablecontinued{\tablename\ \thetable{} \textendash{} continued from previous page}}}\\
\hline

\endhead

\hline
\multicolumn{2}{r}{\makebox[0pt][r]{\sphinxtablecontinued{continues on next page}}}\\
\endfoot

\endlastfoot

{\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.clone.clone:spydrnet.clone.clone}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{clone}}}}}(element)
&
Clone any netlist objects
\\
\hline
\end{longtable}\sphinxatlongtableend\end{savenotes}


\subsection{spydrnet.clone.clone}
\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.clone.clone:spydrnet-clone-clone}}\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.clone.clone::doc}}\index{clone() (in module spydrnet.clone)@\spxentry{clone()}\spxextra{in module spydrnet.clone}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{reference/classes/generated/spydrnet.clone.clone:spydrnet.clone.clone}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{spydrnet.clone.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{clone}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{element}}}{}
Clone any netlist objects
\begin{description}
\item[{several premises hold while cloning}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
the object will be orphaned and not belong to any parent

\item {} 
the object will maintain internal structure with cloned objects

\item {} 
the names will be unchanged

\item {} 
external connections will mostly be severed

\end{itemize}

\item[{Properties}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
cloned using python’s built in deepcopy functionality.

\item {} 
expected to be string objects but if you store something else there make sure you override deepcopy on that object.

\end{itemize}

\item[{Instances have some special considerations}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
when cloned without the library containing the reference definition the instance will still point to the definition of it’s clone.

\item {} 
in the same case as the above point the references of the definition will be updated accordingly

\item {} 
when a library is cloned some of the instances may be defined in another library these instances will follow the premises above

\item {} 
instances defined and referenced in the cloned library will point to the cloned definition

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{fulllineitems}

\appendix
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{tutorial::doc}}

\chapter{Tutorial}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:tutorial}}
SpyDrNet is a tool for the analysis and transformation of structural netlists. A structural netlist is a static
representation of an electronic circuit. A circuit consists of a number of electrical components and their connections.
Figure \hyperref[\detokenize{tutorial:fig-hierarchical-netlist}]{Fig.\@ \ref{\detokenize{tutorial:fig-hierarchical-netlist}}} shows a graphical representation of a netlist.

\begin{figure}[H]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{hierarchical_netlist}.pdf}
\caption{Hierarchical representation of a Netlist}\label{\detokenize{tutorial:id1}}\label{\detokenize{tutorial:fig-hierarchical-netlist}}\end{figure}

Figure \hyperref[\detokenize{tutorial:fig-hierarchical-netlist}]{Fig.\@ \ref{\detokenize{tutorial:fig-hierarchical-netlist}}} represents a netlist hierarchically. This representation is commonly found in
many schematic views of electronic design automation (EDA) or computer aided design (CAD) tools. It presents a top level
instance of a definition that in turn instances other definitions. Instances are connected accordingly and connections
carry through hierarchical boundaries.

Most hardware description languages and netlist representations are capable of representing a structural netlist
hierarchically.

The most basic element of a netlist is a definition. Verilog and System Verilog refer to a definition as
a module. VHDL refers to a definition as an entity. EDIF refers to a definition as a cell. While each language and
framework has a different name, the functioning role of a definition is virtually the same. A definition defines the
interface and contents of a component within a netlist.

An instance is an instantiation of a definition.

Hierarchy organizes larger netlists into
a collection of higher\sphinxhyphen{}level and lower\sphinxhyphen{}level definitions of smaller netlists. Higher\sphinxhyphen{}level definitions instance
lower\sphinxhyphen{}level definitions.


\section{Installation}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:installation}}
For installing instructions, please refer \DUrole{xref,std,std-ref}{INSTALL.rst}


\section{Working Environment}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:working-environment}}
SpyDrNet is coded in Python, and requires Python 3.5 or newer versions of Python. In order to import SpyDrNet to the project, use the following code:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{spydrnet} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n+nn}{sdn}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

In this tutorial, we will use ‘sdn’ as a shorcut for SpyDrNet to manipulate all the commands.


\section{Parsing}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:parsing}}
SpyDrNet currently supports the parsing and composing for EDIF file and Verilog file

To parse a file, enter the following command for EDIF file

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}netlist\PYGZus{}filename\PYGZgt{}.edf}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Or the following for Verilog file

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}netlist\PYGZus{}filename\PYGZgt{}.v}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Nelist is an intermediate representation (IR). We are able to modify the netlist and add new elements. The following code returns the name of the top isntance of the netlist:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{top\PYGZus{}instance}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{name}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

This creates a new library and the library is added to the nestlist. For the entire documentation of SpyDrNet, please refer {\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/index:api-summary}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{API Summary}}}}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{netlist}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{create\PYGZus{}library}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Composing}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:composing}}
To compose a file, enter the following command

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{compose}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{netlist}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}filename\PYGZgt{}.edf}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

A new file named ‘\textless{}filename\textgreater{}.edf’ should be generated in the working directory.


\section{Examples}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:examples}}

\subsection{Creating from scratch}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:creating-from-scratch}}\begin{description}
\item[{We can also create the hardware design from scratch}] \leavevmode
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{spydrnet} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n+nn}{sdn}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{nelist} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Netlist}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{myNetlist}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{instance} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sdn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Instance}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{description}

For full details regarding the initialization of a Netlist obejct, see {\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/netlist:netlist}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Netlist}}}}


\subsection{Renaming an objects}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:renaming-an-objects}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{instance}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{my\PYGZus{}instance}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Setting properties}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:setting-properties}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{instance}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{NAME}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{name}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

For more of the functionality, features, and uses of SpyDrNet, please visit \DUrole{xref,std,std-ref}{sec:examples}

Below is a list of all the intermediate representations (IR) used by SpyDrNet. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/index:api-summary}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{API Summary}}}} for API specification.


\section{Intermediate Representation}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:intermediate-representation}}
SpyDrNet’s intermediate representation of netlists (IR) is what sets it apart for other EDA tools. The IR is structured to house netlists in a generic way while allowing for format specific constructs to be preserved.
\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Element}}}] \leavevmode
Most IR classes inherit from this Python class. Objects of this class are referred to as a netlist elements. A netlist
element contains a dictionary for storing data specific to itself. This is accomplished using Python get/set item
functions, (see {\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/element_data:sec-element-data}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Element Data}}}}).

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Netlist}}}] \leavevmode
This class of Python objects is the netlist element with the highest level of organization (a whole netlist). It
contains an ordered collection of libraries and any data associated with the netlist as a whole.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Library}}}] \leavevmode
This netlist element contains an ordered collection of cell or module definitions associated with a library.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Definition}}}] \leavevmode
A definition outlines the contents of each component that can be instantiated elsewhere in the design. It holds information that is pertinant to all instances of itself including subcomponents ports and connections

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Instance}}}] \leavevmode
This element holds pointers to the definition which it instances, and contains its own set of pins to be connected to within its parent definition.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Bundle}}}] \leavevmode
The Bundle class is a parent class of Ports and Cables because each can be thought of as an array. This class defines the structure that helps us properly represent array objects in netlists including the width, direction (to or downto) and starting index. As a parent class this class is not directly instantiated in netlist.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Port}}}] \leavevmode
The Port element inherits from Bundles and can be thought of as containing the information on how a Definition connects the outside world to the elements it contains.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Cable}}}] \leavevmode
Cables are bundles of connectors between components within a definition. They connect ports to their destination pins

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Pin}}}] \leavevmode
The pin class is also a parent class, inherited from by the inner pin and outer pin objects. Unlike the Element and Bundle objects, Pins are useful because they can hide some of the implementation details of the underlying inner pins and outer pins.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{InnerPin}}}] \leavevmode
These pins are collected in Ports and are contained on the inside of the definitions. There is one set of inner pins per definition but they could refer to several sets of OuterPins

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{OuterPin}}}] \leavevmode
These pins are collected on instances. They let us distinguish between connections to multiple instances of a single definition. These objects remove the need to carefuly track hierarcy while navegating a netlist.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Wire}}}] \leavevmode
Wires are grouped inside cables and are elements that help hold connection information between single pins on instances within a definition and within it’s ports.

\end{description}

More detail on the IR is provided in {\hyperref[\detokenize{reference/classes/index:api-summary}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{API Summary}}}}.
